body: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday made public the names of 72 New York City public high schools whose academic performance was found to be in the bottom 10 percent statewide in a recent state-sponsored survey. In a news briefing at Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, Mr. Quinones reiterated earlier criticisms of the state study,
title: CITY LISTS HIGH SCHOOLS RATED DEFICIENT BY STATE

title: The Results by Voting District in Tuesday's Primary Election

body: Two Long Island runners, Kathy Franey of Massapequa High School and Bill Going of Chaminade in Mineola, posted the best times in New York State this year for the 1,600-meter run at the 18th annual Loucks Games today. Miss Franey, the state indoor champion in the 1,000- and 1,500-meter events and winner of the 1,500-meter run at the Penn Relays last
title: L.I. STARS WINNER IN TRACK

body: Prospect Heights of Brooklyn prevented a sweep by Jamaican schools today in the three championship relays at Franklin Field with the help of three runners who had come from that Carribbean island. Three members of the winning 3,200-meter relay from Prospect Heights - Paul Steele, Leroy Williams and Garfield Dawes - came to Brooklyn three years ago
title: Brooklyn Team Wins

body: Prospect Heights High School, which has only nine boys and eight girls on its track team, yesterday registered the fastest local time this season for the boys' 3,200-meter relay and scored victories in girls' 400- meter and mile medley relays. The Brooklyn school's victories came at the first Redmen track and field invitational meet at St. John's
title: SEASON RELAY MARK SET

body: BY the reckoning of a resident jogger, Prospect Heights is just a mile into Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge. Yet only recently has it become a popular refuge from the high cost of living in Manhattan. Prospect Heights has grown even more attractive as prices continue to rise in neighboring Park Slope, which began its brownstone boom late in the
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: PROSPECT HEIGHTS

body: Shaken by high dropout rates and public outrage over teen-age crime, New York City school officials are launching a new drive to prevent students from leaving high school before graduation. Victor Herbert, who won praise for changing Samuel Gompers Vocational-Technical High School in the South Bronx from a crime-ridden center of academic failure to
title: CITY PLANS NEW EFFORT TO CURB DROPOUT RATE

body: Kathy Franey of Massapequa (L.I.) High School won two events in meet-record times Saturday in the New York State high school indoor track-and-field championships in the Carrier Dome. Miss Franey, a senior, won the 1,000-meter run in 2 minutes 52.09 seconds and the 1,500-meter run in 4:36.6. Two Brooklyn seniors also turned in meet-record victories.
title: L.I. Girl Betters Two State Marks

body: CROWN HEIGHTS is being rediscovered. Regarded for years as a dangerous ghetto, the central Brooklyn neighborhood now attracts many newcomers in search of affordable housing near the more prosperous Park Slope. During the 1950's and 1960's, Crown Heights's population dropped as ethnic and racial composition shifted and poverty and crime discouraged
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CROWN HEIGHTS

body: Lloyd G. Sealy, a 27-year veteran of the New York City Police Department who was the first black man to hold a number of top positions on the force, died of a heart attack Friday, his 68th birthday. He lived in Brooklyn. Mr. Sealy was stricken as he taught a class at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt
title: LLOYD SEALY, THE FIRST BLACK MAN IN SEVERAL HIGH POLICE POSTS, DIES

body: Lloyd G. Sealy, a 28-year veteran of the New York City police department who was the first black man to hold a number of top positions on the force, died of a heart attack yesterday, a police spokesman said. He turned 68 years old yesterday and lived in Brooklyn. Mr. Sealy was stricken as he taught a class at the John Jay College of Criminal
title: LLOYD G. SEALY IS DEAD AT 69; HELD HIGH POSTS WITH POLICE
